Award.AwardTitle: Research at the Intensity Frontier with the LHCb Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
The physics program at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland is in full operation, now delivering proton-proton collisions at 8 TeVcollision energy. The Syracuse group is a member of the LHCb experiment which is currently in an intense data-taking phase for 2012, and which will segue into an analysis and upgrade phase during the period 2013-2014. Afterward, operations will resume at 14 TeV collision energy. The LHCb experiment is designed to study beauty and charm decays at a hadron collider and the experiment and the Syracuse group are well-positioned to: (1) make direct measurements of the production and decay properties of these particles, and (2) simultaneously have sensitivity to new physics at high mass scales through the attendant effects of such physics on decay rates, CP violating asymmetries, or polarizations of certain vector states in the beauty and charm particle decays.

Syracuse contributes significantly to the physics program including: measurement of the b-bbar production cross section, determination of b-hadron branching fractions, discovery of a new semileptonic decays of strange neutral B mesons, including first observation of CP Violation in the decay of the strange neutral B meson into a J/psi and f meson. The group is aggressively pursuing these analyses and measuring the CP violating angle gamma and lifetimes of strange neutral B mesons.

In technical and service responsibility to LHCb, Syracuse participation has been very broad, with contributions to the Vertex Locator, Trigger, and Ring Imaging Cherenkov detector testing, and ongoing LHCb operations. The group is active in detector research and development with emphasis on new technologies for the upgraded vertex detector and responsibility for silicon based downstream tracking. The Syracuse group is active in the research and development of highly radiation resistant semiconductor detectors, capable of surviving the vigorous conditions expected at the High Luminosity LHC, and in the development of diamond tracking detectors.

Throughout its research program, Syracuse has maintained an active interest in broadening participation. The group has recently joined QuarkNet and maintains an "Ask a Particle Physicist" website, so that teachers and other members of the community can interact informally with the group. And the group actively encourages and supports younger members of the research team to be actively engaged in the high school classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impacts of our work include our education of undergraduate and graduate students. Undergraduates work in out laboratory and gain experience with ``hands on science.” The participate in many activities including assembling electronics, machining parts, and mechanical construction. Graduate students participate in these activities but in addition receive a substantial education in data analysis and data mining. We educate high school teachers in basic particle physics via our participation in the QuarkNet program.  Out reach to the general public is provided via our  “Education Outreach” webpage (http://hepoutreach.syr.edu/index.html ) which provides general information about our group and particle physics in general, with a link to our “Ask a Particle Physicist” website ( http://hepoutreach.syr.edu/Ask_A_Physicist/index.html )where the general public can as the faculty questions via the web.

 

The intellectual merit of our activities consists of two efforts. One is to construct a detector that tracks particles for the upgraded LHCb detector called the UT, and the other is to analyze data and publish new research on particle decays. The UT detector is scheduled to be finished in 2019. The last three years were  mostly in a design phase that led to a great deal of prototyping and testing during the last year. Construction should begin at the end of 2015.

 

We have contributed enormously to the physics output of the LHCb experiment. In the last three years the LHCb experiment has submitted approximately 180 papers for publication and our group has been the lead author on 34 of these. The latest is the discovery of two exotic baryon states called ``charmonium pentaquarks,” for which most of the work was done during the last year of this grant. These particles are different than heretofore known baryon states because they contain five quarks rather than the normal three. We also have provided the most accurate determinations of the lifetimes of several species of particles containing the b quark, including the Λb, the Ξb and the Bs. Also of high importance are our measurements of violations of CP asymmetry. This symmetry is required for the Universe to have evolved from its initial state to our current state of matter domination, the anti-matter having decayed away. We have made measurements of different types of CP violation in the Bs system
